Methacrolein is an important intermediate in the fine chemical industry, and its synthesis has garnered significant attention from researchers. In this study, sixteen bifunctional heterogeneous catalysts (designated as PILCN-x) were synthesized. The activity of the catalyst was evaluated based on the synthesis of methacrolein from formaldehyde and propionaldehyde, with PILCN-II identified as the most effective catalyst. The optimal catalyst PILCN-II was characterized by FT-IR, SEM, BET, 1H NMR, 13C NMR, XPS and TGA. The effects of various reaction conditions, including solvent, acid, and reaction temperature, on catalytic performance were investigated in detail. The results showed that the optimum reaction conditions were as follows: DMF was used as the solvent; the catalyst dosage was 0.85 g; the formaldehyde/propionaldehyde molar ratio was maintained at 1:1; the reaction temperature was 70 °C; and the reaction time was 50 min. Under the optimal reaction conditions, the conversion rate of propionaldehyde was up to 99.09 %, and the yield of methacrolein was 98.70 %. Notably, after 5 reaction cycles, the catalytic activity of PILCN-II did not decrease significantly. In order to determine the reaction conditions more accurately, the response surface methodology was used, and the fitting results were in good agreement with the experimental results. Finally, kinetic studies showed that the reaction catalyzed by PILCN-II followed quasi-first-order kinetics. Additionally, it serves as a precursor in the synthesis of unsaturated esters [5,6], diacetates [7,8], thermoplastics [9], and other compounds. Given its extensive applications, high profitability, and significant utility, the domestic demand for MAL continues to rise, prompting increased attention and in-depth research in this area. The synthesis of MAL was typically achieved using one of three approaches: the direct aldol process [10], selective oxidation of isobutene/isobutane [11], or a secondary amine-catalyzed Mannich reaction involving propionaldehyde (PA) and formaldehyde (FA) [12–15]. The direct aldol condensation generally requires strong base catalysis. Li et al. [16] investigated this pathway by testing various strong bases, including sodium hydroxide, diethylamine and triethylamine as catalysts. Their further investigations revealed that diethylamine exhibited the best catalytic performance. While the conversion of FA could reach 97 % with this catalyst, the selectivity for MAL was only 10.1 % [17,18]. The use of strong bases in the condensation reaction is problematic because their high alkalinity can lead to the formation of the by-product 2-methyl-2-pentenal [19]. The presence of by-products results in low selectivity, and the corrosive nature of strong alkalis can damage equipment, significantly hindering the development of this method. In contrast, the selective oxidation of isobutene/isobutane typically employs metal oxides as catalysts. Gu and Moens et al. [20–22] used Mo-Bi complex as a catalyst to selectively oxidize isobutylene to MAL. They reported that at reaction temperature exceeding 380 °C, the conversion rate of isobutylene could reach 90 %, with the MAL yield above 80 %. However, the high reaction temperature raises safety concerns for industrial scale-up processes. The Mannich reaction catalyzed by secondary amines offers advantages such as short reaction time and mild reaction conditions [23,24]. Consequently, the application of Mannich reaction in MAL synthesis has been deeply studied. At present, ionic liquid catalysts and resin catalysts are mainly employed for MAL production through Mannich reactions. Ionic liquids have excellent properties such as low volatility, thermal stability and chemical stability, making them promising candidates for MAL synthesis [25–28]. For instance, Fan et al. [29] used acetic acid and diethylamine as catalysts, achieving a PA conversion rate of 99.5% and the MAL yield of 97.9% at 45 °C. Furthermore, they identified that temperature and concentration significantly impacted catalyst deactivation. On this basis, Yan et al. [30] used isotope tracer tests to investigate the reaction mechanism and capture the intermediates, discovering that l-proline [31] and morpholine [32] exhibited significant catalytic efficiency. Although the homogeneous catalysts showed strong catalytic activity, they still faced great challenges in their separation and recovery. In order to solve the problems of separation and recovery, researchers continued to improve the catalyst and develop a resin catalyst. For example, Zhong et al. [33], using 330-resin as a catalyst, first reacted at 45 °C for 50 min, followed by heating to 75 °C for 70 min. Under these conditions, the conversion rate of PA reached 99.5 % and the selectivity of MAL reached 93.1 %. The catalyst solves the problems of separation and recovery, while the reaction steps are cumbersome, limiting its applicability in industrial production. In this study, in order to overcome the difficulties of catalyst separation and recovery and the complicated reaction steps, we prepared a bifunctional heterogeneous catalyst that is easily separated. The effects of reaction time, reaction temperature, catalyst dosage, the molar ratio and TOF on the synthesis of MAL from FA and PA were investigated. The stability of the catalyst was investigated, and the reaction conditions were further verified by the response surface method. Finally, the reaction mechanism and kinetics were discussed. 2 Experiments 2.1 Chemical reagents The chemical reagents of propionaldehyde (PA, purity 97.0 %), formaldehyde solution (FA, purity 37 %), anhydrous ethanol (purity 99.5 %), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, purity 99.5 %), methanol (purity 99.5 %), methylbenzene (purity 99.8 %), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, purity 90 %) and diallylamine (purity 99 %) are analytically pure and were purchased from Aladdin Reagent (Shanghai) Co., Ltd. 2,2′-azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN, purity 98.0 %), divinylbenzene (DVB, purity 80.0 %) and methacrylic acid (purity 99.0 %) were gained from Shanghai Macklin Co., Ltd. 2.2 Preparation of catalyst The ionic liquid monomer was synthesized by mixing methacrylic acid (8.61 g, 0.1 mol) and diallylamine (9.72 g, 0.1 mol) in a three-neck flask in an ice bath for 3 h. At the conclusion of the reaction, 0.85 g AIBN and 13.02 g DVB were added and the mixture was sonicated for 20 min to ensure uniformity. Under a nitrogen atmosphere, the mixture was reacted at 80 °C for 6 h resulting in the formation of a solid polymer. After the reaction, the solid polymer was filtered, washed with distilled water three times, and dried in an oven at 80 °C to obtain the desired catalyst. This catalyst was named as PILCN-I, and the synthesis route of polymerized ionic liquid catalyst was briefly illustrated in Scheme 1 . Additionally, by varying the amount of DVB and replacing methacrylic acid with other acids (such as replacing methacrylic acid with acrylic acid), polymers with different hydrophobicity can be synthesized. The preparation of these polymers followed the same method as described above, and the resulting catalysts with different acid and divinylbenzene content were summarized in Table 1 . 2.3 Catalyst characterization The specific surface area and porosity of the catalyst were tested with the ASAP2460 instrument (American Micromeritics Instrument Co., Ltd.). In the experiment, N2 was used as the adsorption gas, and the temperature of the analysis tank was 77.350 K. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were obtained on a Nicolet-380 FT-IR spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) using KBr as diluent. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was acquired using the ESCALAB 250Xi (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) spectrometer with Al Kα radiation at θ = 90° and the C 1S peak of 284.8 eV was used as the reference standard for binding energy calibration. The 1H-MAS-NMR characterization was performed on the Bruker AVANCE III HD 600 instrument. The 13C-MAS-NMR characterization was conducted on Bruker AVANCE instrument (500 MHz) with cross-polarization contacting time of 2000 μs loop delay time of 5 s, magic angle tilt of 54.74° and rotor speed of 12,000 Hz. The thermal stability of the catalysts was studied using the SDT-2960 thermogravimetric analyzer (TA, USA) and their weightless behavior at different temperatures was determined. The surface morphology of the catalyst was observed using the S-4800-I scanning electron microscope (Hitachi, Japan) to gain insight into its physical properties. The contact Angle was tested at 25 °C on LSA60 (LAUDA Scientific, Germany). 2.4 Catalyst performance evaluation The reactants, PA (0.02 mol, 1.84 g), FA (0.02 mol, 1.18 g), along with DMF solvent and catalyst were placed in a three-neck flask. This flask was then positioned in a constant temperature oil bath equipped with magnetic stirring. Upon completion of the reaction, the flask was immersed in ice water to quench the reaction. The amount of catalyst was maintained at 0.45–0.85 g, the reaction temperature was set at 40–80 °C, the reaction time was controlled at 20–60 min, and the molar ratio of FA to PA was kept at 0.7:1–1.3:1. The product was subsequently analyzed by gas chromatography (GC-7900, Shanghai Tianmei Scientific Instrument Co., Ltd.) and its composition was determined. Gas chromatography detection was performed using a flame ionization detector (FID), with the following conditions: the inlet temperature was set to 160 °C, and the detector temperature was maintained at 160 °C. The column box temperature was programmed as follows: the initial column temperature was set to 43 °C and increased at a rate of 3 °C/min to 65 °C for 1 min. The temperature was then ramped at 20 °C/min to 130 °C for 1 min, and finally increased at 40 °C/min to 160 °C for 1 min. The catalytic performance of the catalyst was evaluated according to the conversion rate of PA(XPA), selectivity of MAL (SMAL)and yield of MAL(YMAL). The corresponding expressions for these parameters are as follows: (1) X PA = n PA 0 − n PA , t n PA 0 × 100 % (2) S MAL = n MAL , t n PA 0 − n PA , t × 100 % (3) Y M A L = X P A × S M A L In these equations, nPA,0 and nPA,t are the initial molar amount of amount of PA and the molar amount of PA after t minutes of reaction. nMAL,t is the molar amount of MAL synthesized in the system at the end of the reaction. 2.5 Catalyst regeneration After the reaction was completed, the catalyst was separated from the reaction system by filtration and washed with water and ethanol 3 to 4 times. The washed catalyst was then dried for 1 hour in a vacuum oven at 80 °C to be used in the next reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Screening of catalyst The catalytic performance of 16 catalysts for MAL synthesis was screened. The results are shown in Fig. 1 . It can be clearly seen from Fig. 1 that the catalytic performance of the catalyst prepared with methacrylic acid is significantly better than that of the other acid catalysts, with PILCN-Ⅱ demonstrating the best catalytic performance. Consequently, we focused on the characterization of catalysts prepared with methacrylic acid. In the subsequent experiments, PILCN-Ⅱ was used to investigate the influence of various factors on the synthesis of MAL. 3.2 Catalyst characterization 3.2.1 Infrared spectral analysis Infrared spectroscopy was used to characterize the synthesized hydrophobic bifunctional polymeric ionic liquid catalyst, and the results were shown in Fig. 2 . Firstly, the infrared absorption peak at 3431 cm−1 was attributed to the stretching vibration of the NH bond in diallylamine [34–36]. The characteristic peak at 1705 cm−1 corresponds to the stretching vibration of the -COOH group [37–41]. The reaction was carried out at a temperature of 80 °C for 30 min, with a molar ratio of FA to PA of 1:1, and ethanol was used as the solvent. The dosage of catalyst used varied, and the results were shown in Fig. 11(a). The experimental results indicated that with the increase of catalyst dosage, the conversion of PA and MAL yield increased first, and then plateaued. Notably, when the catalyst dosage reached 0.85 g, the conversion of PA reached 99.74 %, with a corresponding MAL yield of 86.23 %. Therefore, the optimum catalyst dosage for this reaction was determined to be 0.85 g. Then, the effect of solvent on the aldol condensation reaction involving FA and PA was investigated. Keeping other reaction conditions constant, solvents with different permittivity were added, and the results were shown in Fig. 10 . The results showed that the yield of MAL initially increased and then decreased with increasing solvent permittivity. When DMF with a permittivity of 36.7 was used as the solvent, PA conversion reached 98.74 %, resulting in a MAL yield of 93.00 %. This study confirms that polar solvents are advantageous for the synthesis of MAL. The primary reason for this observation is that when a polar solvent is employed, the polymer catalyst and reactants are well-dispersed, which enhances contact with the active centers, thereby facilitating the reaction [48,62]. The effect of reaction time on this reaction was subsequently investigated. All other reaction conditions were kept unchanged while the reaction time was varied. The results were presented in Fig. 11 (b). The experimental results indicated that the yield and selectivity of MAL increased with longer reaction time, specifically within the range of 20 min to 50 min. At 50 °C, the conversion rate of PA reached 98.66 %, and the yield of MAL reached 98.33 %. As the reaction time increased, the conversion rate tended to stabilize, but the yield of MAL dropped sharply. Thus, the optimal reaction time for this reaction was identified as 50 min. This decline can be attributed to the fact that as the reaction time increases, the reaction gradually proceeds further, causing the content of MAL in the system to gradually increase. At higher MAL content levels, MAL molecules may undergo self-polymerization, forming dimeric or polymeric by-products, resulting in lower yield [48]. The effect of reaction temperature on the process was studied under the following conditions: a reaction time of 50 min, a catalyst dosage of 0.85 g, DMF as the solvent, a molar ratio of FA to PA of 1:1. The temperature was changed and the corresponding effects on the results were shown in Fig. 11(c). From the figure, it can be seen that both the conversion of PA and the yield of MAL increased with rising temperature within the range of 40 to 70 °C. At 70 °C, the conversion rate of PA reached 99.74 %, and the yield of MAL was 89.90 %. However, when the temperature exceeded 70 °C, both the conversion rate of PA and the yield of MAL began to decline. The results indicated that the optimum temperature for this reaction was 70 °C. This decline can be attributed to the fact that the high temperature could promote side reaction, leading to a decrease in the yield of MAL [13,51]. Finally, the effect of the molar ratio of FA to PA was studied. The results were shown in Fig. 11(d). When the molar ratio of FA to PA was in the range of 0.7:1 to 1:1, an increase in the FA content corresponded with an increase in the conversion of PA. However, as the molar amount of FA increased further, the conversion of PA tended to stabilize, while the selectivity and yield of MAL decrease rapidly. When the molar ratio was 1:1, the conversion of PA reached 99.09 %, and the highest yield of MAL was 98.70 %. Therefore, it can be concluded that the optimal molar ratio of the reaction is 1:1. 3.4 Repeatability test In order to evaluate the catalytic stability of the catalyst, catalyst recycling experiments were carried out under the optimal reaction conditions. The results are shown in Fig. 12 . The results showed that the conversion rate of PA and the yield of MAL were almost unchanged after 5 cycles of catalyst reuse. When compared with other heterogeneous catalysts such as Cs-P/γ-Al2O3, Mg3Al-Pro-LDHs, poly[DVB-(4-APAC)1.0]s, PILCN-Ⅱ demonstrated significant advantages in terms of reaction time, reaction temperature, and yield. First, the nucleophilic attack of the carbonyl carbon of FA by the amino group of the polymer catalyst (I) by the carbonyl carbon of FA, leading to the formation of the amino carbinol structure (II) [51]. This amino carbinol (II) then undergoes dehydration to yield the iminium ion intermediate (III). The subsequent step involves the condensation of the iminium ion intermediate (III) with the enolate of PA, resulting in the formation of the Mannich base (IV). Following this, a proton transfer occurs from the carboxyl group of (I) to the Mannich base (IV), generating the ammonium ion intermediate (V) [29]. Subsequently, the intermediate (Ⅵ) is formed through the migration of Cα-H from the carboxylic acid group. The final step in the mechanism is the cleavage of the CN bond in intermediate (VI), yielding the desired product MAL [49]. 3.8 Study on reaction kinetics The kinetics of the reaction was studied under the optimal conditions, and the experimental results were shown in Fig. 20. The optimal reaction conditions were as follows: DMF was used as a solvent, the catalyst dosage was 0.85 g, the molar ratio of FA to PA was 1:1, the reaction temperature was 70 °C and the reaction time was 50 min. Under these optimal conditions, the conversion of PA was up to 99.09 %, and the yield of MAL was 98.70 %. The catalytic activity of the catalyst was not significantly reduced after five reuse cycles. The reaction catalyzed by PILCN- II followed first-order kinetics. To further validate the accuracy of the reaction conditions, response surface methodology was employed. Response surface analysis showed a strong agreement with the experimental results, confirming the reliability of the optimal response conditions. Finally, the reaction mechanism for the conversion of FA and PA to MAL was discussed. The results indicated that the catalytic performance of the PILCN-II was nearly equivalent to that of the homogeneous catalyst. The catalyst offers several advantages, such as mild reaction conditions, negligible equipment corrosion, easy separation. So, this catalyst has great development prospects in industrial applications. coredata.dc:description: Methacrolein is an important intermediate in the fine chemical industry, and its synthesis has garnered significant attention from researchers. In this study, sixteen bifunctional heterogeneous catalysts (designated as PILCN-x) were synthesized. The activity of the catalyst was evaluated based on the synthesis of methacrolein from formaldehyde and propionaldehyde, with PILCN-II identified as the most effective catalyst. The optimal catalyst PILCN-II was characterized by FT-IR, SEM, BET, 1H NMR, 13C NMR, XPS and TGA. The effects of various reaction conditions, including solvent, acid, and reaction temperature, on catalytic performance were investigated in detail. The results showed that the optimum reaction conditions were as follows: DMF was used as the solvent; the catalyst dosage was 0.85 g; the formaldehyde/propionaldehyde molar ratio was maintained at 1:1; the reaction temperature was 70 °C; and the reaction time was 50 min. Under the optimal reaction conditions, the conversion rate of propionaldehyde was up to 99.09 %, and the yield of methacrolein was 98.70 %. Notably, after 5 reaction cycles, the catalytic activity of PILCN-II did not decrease significantly. In order to determine the reaction conditions more accurately, the response surface methodology was used, and the fitting results were in good agreement with the experimental results. Finally, kinetic studies showed that the reaction catalyzed by PILCN-II followed quasi-first-order kinetics.
